results.title: The Hungry miles
results.creator_credit: Jerome Levy, Keith Gow, Norma Disher and Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia. Film Unit.
results.brief_description: A passionate survey of the struggles and achievements of the Waterside Workers Federation including some striking scenes of the depression (reconstructed by the WWF Film Unit with amateur actors), showing the impact of the economic hardships of the 1930s on the union and its members.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jerome Levy, Keith Gow, Norma Disher and Waterside Workers’ Federation of Australia. Film Unit.

results.title: The Hunger machine. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Ian McFarlane, Chris Bryer and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Politics of food”.
Feeding the hungry of the world is not just an exercise in good agricultural practices or a result of foreign aid and trade. Governments can affect farmers by imposing tarrifs or providing subsidies so that even in times of surplus, the needy may be disadvantaged. More productive agricultural programmes can increase food supply, however in developing countries who receive aid and food, the incentive to develop these practices may not be encouraged by the political forces in power.

results.title: The Hunger
results.brief_description: The Hunger seamlessly melds gothic horror with a chic, contemporary edge in this erotic tale of sex, blood and desire. The icily beautiful vampire Miriam (Catherine Deneuve) and her latest consort, John (David Bowie), spend their nights scanning the hottest nightclubs in New York for new prey. When John suddenly begins to age at an alarming rate, they seek out Sarah Roberts (Susan Sarandon), a doctor researching links between blood disease and ageing. Disbelieving at first, Sarah rapidly becomes enmeshed in the nightmarish reality of Miriam’s world. Based upon the novel of the same name by best-selling author Whitley Strieber.

results.title: The Hundredth monkey
results.brief_description: We all want to know what we can do about peace but few feel we can really make a difference. The Hundredth Monkey Phenomenon proves we can. The film reviews the research that shows how the thoughts of individuals affect the world. While feeding monkeys sweet potatoes on a Japanese island, a group of scientists discovered that when a critical number of monkeys learned a behaviour, all the monkeys in the tribe began exhibiting the same behaviour - without being taught. Ken Keyes brought attention to this research with his book “The Hundredth monkey”, and he introduces the concept in this film. Both the book and the video support the notion that when awareness of an idea reaches a critical level, this awareness spreads exponentially and becomes universal.

results.title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame (Silent)
results.creator_credit: Wallace Worsley, Irving G. Thalberg, Carl Laemmle and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: This classic silent film of the Victor Hugo novel is a masterpiece of film-making. Lon Chaney as the hunchback Quasimodo was grotesque and pathetic. The actor suffered for his art in a rubber suit weighing over seventy pounds. Dubbed “The man of a thousand faces”, Chaney’s portrayal of Quasimodo is not the only outstanding feature of this production. The set which took a year to build, the enormous cast of extras, adds to the epic grandeur of the film. Starring Brandon Hurst, Nigel De Brulier and Patsy Ruth Miller as Esmeralda.

results.title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame (Laughton)
results.creator_credit: William Dieterle and Pandro S. Berman
results.brief_description: William Dieterle’s film of Victor Hugo’s magnificent novel “Notre Dame de Paris” is a beautifully fashioned, powerful and dramatic work with an unforgettable visual impression. Charles Laughton plays Quasimodo, the hideously deformed, tragic hunchback. Maureen O’Hara plays the enchanting Esmeralda. Rated: PG

results.title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame (Disney)
results.creator_credit: Kirk Wise, Gary Trousdale, Don Hahn and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: Animated musical Disney version of Victor Hugo’s gothic novel “The Hunchback of Notre Dame.” Quasimodo is a hunchback who was rescued by a kindly priest, just as he was to be cast down a well. Now an adult, Quasimodo is employed as bell ringer at the monastery, but is an outcast and a prisoner in his bell tower, by order of his master Judge Frollo. During a carnival, Quasimodo is taunted by the merciless crowd and about to be flogged when a beautiful and spirited gypsy woman named Esmeralda intervenes. Frollo, a treacherous man who loathes gypsies, falls in lust with Esmeralda, who enrages him further by spurning his advances and mocking him. Esmeralda meanwhile has fallen for the handsome Phoebus, despite feeling compassion for the brutalised Quasimodo. Unlike other Disney productions, “The Hunchback of Notre Dame” entertains darker themes of racism, desire and rebellion, and the animation matches the sinister undercurrents of the book. The animation is impressive, (at times recalling “Fantasia”) as is the voice work of Tom Hulce, Demi Moore and Kevin Kline. Deviating from the original novel, comic relief is provided in the order of numerous gargoyles that befriend Quasimodo.

results.title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame
results.brief_description: When Quasimodo defies the evil Frollo and ventures out to the Festival of Fools, the cruel crowd jeers him. Rescued by fellow outcast the gypsy Esmeralda, Quasi soon finds himself battling to save the people and the city he loves.

constellations_other.name: Sweet Country
constellations_other.description: Warwick Thornton’s feature film Sweet Country is based on the story of Wilaberta Jack, which was told to sound recordist David Tranter by his grandfather and translated into storyboards.

results.title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame
results.brief_description: In 15th century France, a gypsy girl is framed for murder by the infatuated Chief Justice, and only the deformed bellringer of Notre Dame Cathedral can save her.

constellations_other.name: Sweet Country

results.title: The Hunchback of Notre-Dame = Notre Dame de Paris
results.creator_credit: Jean Delannoy, Raymond Hakim, Betty Edmonds, Robert Edmonds, Allied Artists Pictures and Cocinor
results.brief_description: Anthony Quinn plays the deformed hunchbacked bell-ringer Quasimodo and Gina Lollobrigida stars as the beautiful gypsy dancing girl Esmeralda in this French/Italian adaptation of Victor Hugo’s all-time classic novel about friendship, love and loyalty. Lavish sets, costume and make-up, along with a cast of thousands, are used to create a historical epic in the style of such films as “The Ten commandments” and “Ben Hur”, but unfortunately does not quite succeed in the same way that these films did. The dialogue at times is perhaps overdone and the film comes across more as a theatrical presentation, lacking a sense of realism. However this is not to take away from Anthony Quinn and Gina Lollobrigida’s solid performances in their respective roles. Cast also includes Alaine Cuny, Jean Danet, Robert Hirsch, Danielle Dumont, Philippe Clay. NOTE: This film is partially dubbed.
